channel.title: Checking .jar for viruses
channel.description: I downloaded a server that one of my internet friends programmed and wanted me to try out. Now I'm thinking it's a virus and I can't delete it. How could I check if it runs a .exe or if it's malicious? (Or if someone else wants to check for me, I can PM you a link, but don't run it).

item.title: Checking .jar for viruses
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

whackatre:

What does running your programs in a sandbox effecitly do, and how do you do that?

Running it in a sandboxed mode (not sure if it’s possible with Java) basically uses the sandbox as the environment, so any sort of instant malicious changes would be visible, and no harm would be done to your actual system. However, some virus react to a trigger (packet, date, etc) so the damage may not be immediate, or even known.

Read full topic

item.title: Checking .jar for viruses
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

What does running your programs in a sandbox effecitly do, and how do you do that?

Read full topic

item.title: Checking .jar for viruses
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Daginith, post:13, topic:437360”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=540069.msg3957275#msg3957275 date=1332886155]
The easiest way is to decompile the source, and look for anything weird (ie. Runtime.exec(“del C:”); or something similar)

Otherwise, you could run it in a sandboxed mode is suppose
[/quote]
del C://…if that was the case, they wouldn’t be able to look for it >.>[/quote]

It was an example of blatantly obvious malicious code. It could be a logic bomb

if (System.currentTimeMillis() >= DECEMBER_21_2012) {
    // make the computer part of a botnet
}

Or upload a map of a person’s filesystem to a server

for (File f : getDirectoryListings("C:/")) {
    parseRecursiveListing(f);
    buildMap();
    uploadMap();
}

Or, something as simple as a back door

ServerSocket backdoor = new ServerSocket(RANDOM_PORT);
CommandParser parser = new CommandParser(backdoor);

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith

Otherwise, you could run it in a sandboxed mode is suppose[/quote]
del C://…if that was the case, they wouldn’t be able to look for it >.>

item.title: Checking .jar for viruses
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Daginith, post:8, topic:437360”][quote author=vManlyMan link=topic=540069.msg3954434#msg3954434 date=1332615608]

what i suggest you do is DL, the .jar, (Dont run it) and decompile it, then check out the .java files for malicious content.

I was asking how to do this. I probably couldn’t open a java file if it was decompiled for me, let alone decompile it myself.
[/quote]
extract it with winrar or 7z (Assuming your on windows), so you get all the .class files
then decompile those with JAD which you can download here: http://www.varaneckas.com/jad
then check out the .java files if they are downloading any .dll files to your computer, or any other files becides the cache
if it is, find the file, and delete it.[/quote]

Sometimes, well-hidden code is well-hidden.

If this is the current case with private servers, well, I feel sorry for those kids who play so many different private servers that their entire C drive is filled with stupid caches. I wonder how many Java drive-by’s they get.

Read full topic

item.title: Checking .jar for viruses
item.dc:creator: @youridudock youridudock
item.description:
@youridudock wrote:

Or just download Winpatrol and check if there are any strange programs running or in the computer startup. (Registery)

Read full topic

item.title: Checking .jar for viruses
item.dc:creator: @waj waj
item.description:
@waj wrote:

Or just download JD-GUI and drag the jar file into it and have a quick search through some files if you’re looking for the easiest option.

Read full topic

item.title: Checking .jar for viruses
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

[quote=“vManlyMan, post:7, topic:437360”][quote author=Daginith link=topic=540069.msg3954430#msg3954430 date=1332615391]
what i suggest you do is DL, the .jar, (Dont run it) and decompile it, then check out the .java files for malicious content.
[/quote]

I was asking how to do this. I probably couldn’t open a java file if it was decompiled for me, let alone decompile it myself.[/quote]
extract it with winrar or 7z (Assuming your on windows), so you get all the .class files
then decompile those with JAD which you can download here: http://www.varaneckas.com/jad
then check out the .java files if they are downloading any .dll files to your computer, or any other files becides the cache
if it is, find the file, and delete it.

Read full topic

Daginith:

what i suggest you do is DL, the .jar, (Dont run it) and decompile it, then check out the .java files for malicious content.

I was asking how to do this. I probably couldn’t open a java file if it was decompiled for me, let alone decompile it myself.

Read full topic

item.title: Checking .jar for viruses
item.dc:creator: @vManlyMan vManlyMan
item.description:
@vManlyMan wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:4, topic:437360”][quote author=vManlyMan link=topic=540069.msg3954377#msg3954377 date=1332612791]

… usually you can right click the jar and scan it ;p

I thought virus scanners don’t check java files. Am I wrong?
[/quote]
you are not wrong, but its possible you just have a running java process. open up your task manager and kill all java.exe then try to delete.[/quote]

I restarted my computer and was able to delete it fine, so you were probably right about the java process. Thanks Silab. Can lock this now.

Read full topic

I thought virus scanners don’t check java files. Am I wrong?[/quote]
you are not wrong, but its possible you just have a running java process. open up your task manager and kill all java.exe then try to delete.
